title: Alaska Is Buying Up Apple, GE, Microsoft, and Boeing Stock
paragraphs: Alaska’s motto is “North to the future,” but the state’s revenue department also sees the future in some large-cap stocks it bought up in the third quarter.

The Alaska Department of Revenue, which collects and invests public funds, increased investments in Apple (ticker: AAPL), General Electric (GE), Microsoft (MSFT), and Boeing (BA). The latest moves mark a bit of a reversal. The state had sold Apple and Microsoft stock in the first quarter and essentially stood pat on the names in the second quarter. With the stock market’s October swoon, it is too early to tell which of these purchases were prescient; three of the four stocks are down—along with the S&P 500 index—in the nascent fourth quarter. Only Apple has risen, sporting a 1.4% gain so far in October.

The agency didn’t respond to a request for comment on its stock trades or strategy. As of Sept. 30, it oversaw $7.4 billion in publicly traded securities, according to a form the Alaska Department of Revenue filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Alaska bought 160,792 additional Apple shares in the third quarter, lifting its investment to 789,587 shares of the iPhone maker. The stock has soared 43.9% this year through Friday’s close, despite trade-war fears, more than wiping out last year’s 6.8% drop. Apple stock is trouncing the S&P 500, which is holding on to a 17.8% year-to-date gain after a rough start to October.

GE stock sports a 17.8% year-to-date gain. That may be surprising, considering that the conglomerate’s bears haven’t backed down, and that a report that alleged fraud—a charge forcefully denied by GE. CEO Larry Culp told us that he looks forward to the company’s continued progress. “This is a game of inches,” he said. Alaska’s Department of Revenue is on board. It bought 455,972 additional GE shares in the third quarter, ending September with 1.55 million shares.

The state’s revenue department also bought 455,972 more shares of Microsoft in the quarter, raising its holdings to 1.43 million shares of the software giant. Microsoft stock is having a boffo year, rising 36.0% in 2019. Earnings have been strong and the company raised the dividend last month. Microsoft also seems to be willing to engage old rival Apple by unveiling tablets, earbuds, and a new phone.

Boeing stock is up 16.5% in 2019, even though its 737 MAX plane looks like it will remain grounded for the time being. We’ve speculated that CEO Dennis Muilenburg could take off before the embattled 737 MAX. “If an activist showed up at Boeing, Dennis Muilenburg would be cooked,” an analyst told us. Nonetheless, Alaska’s Department of Revenue bulked up its Boeing investment by a third by buying an additional 24,491 shares to end the third quarter with 96,145 shares.

Inside Scoop is a regular Barron’s feature covering stock transactions by corporate executives and board members—so-called insiders—as well as large shareholders, politicians, and other prominent figures. Due to their insider status, these investors are required to disclose stock trades with the Securities and Exchange Commission or other regulatory groups.
